aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Stinson 108-2 in Halfway, Missouri
Halfway is a location in Missouri.
The accident occurred on December 5, 2012.
The accident occurred at 13:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Stinson 108-2.
The aircraft registration was N8775K.
The defining event of the accident was loss of engine power (total).
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN13LA091.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The accident resulted in 1 minor injury.
The private pilot was operating the aircraft.
The airplane was in cruise flight when the engine made an unusual grinding noise.
The engine stopped producing power after making the grinding noise.
The pilot made a forced landing to a field.
During the emergency descent, the airplane struck a power line with the left main landing gear.
The airplane landed hard after striking the power line.
Examination of the engine revealed the magnetos were not properly secured to the engine.
Examination of the engine revealed the camshaft was broken.
The airplane's most recent annual inspection was completed in January 2008.
The annual inspection was completed almost 5 years before the accident.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's failure to properly maintain the airplane and engine.
The failure to properly maintain the airplane resulted in a total loss of engine power.
The total loss of engine power was due to improperly installed magnetos and a broken camshaft.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Aircraft (general) - Failure" as a finding.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Personnel issues - Scheduled/routine maintenance - Pilot" as a finding.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Halfway, Missouri

## Date & Time: 
December 5, 2012, 13:00 Local

## Aircraft:
Stinson 108-2

## Defining Event:
Loss of engine power (total)

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN13LA091

## Registration:
N8775K

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 Minor

## Analysis

The private pilot said the airplane was in cruise flight when the engine made an unusual grinding noise and then stopped producing power. The pilot made a forced landing to a field. During the emergency descent, the airplane struck a power line with the left main landing gear and landed hard. Examination of the engine revealed that the magnetos were not properly secured to the engine and that the camshaft was broken. A review of the engine maintenance logbook revealed the airplane's most recent annual inspection was completed in January 2008, almost 5 years before the accident.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's failure to properly maintain the airplane and engine, which resulted in a total loss of engine power due to improperly installed magnetos and a broken camshaft.

## Findings

| Aircraft | (general) - Failure |
| --- | --- |
| Personnel issues | Scheduled/routine maintenance - Pilot |

---
